questions.neutral: Did you slip in easy tonight?

hobby.message: I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Made it in. Slow going outside, but I managed.
I fold origami. Just scraps, simple ones.
Harder lately with all the outages.
People make it difficult to concentrate.
Slipped in alright. Not much hassle tonight.
Been folding origami again. Keeps me busy.
Had to use bus schedules for paper—system shutdown ruined my stash.
Doesn’t help when you’re used to some quiet.
Origami gets trickier without the usual routine.
Came in without trouble. Place is quieter since the blackout.
I do origami at home—tessellations, sometimes modular pieces.
Newspapers work, but the paper’s too rough.
Lost my favorite folding spot during the outages.
Miss the days when nobody bothered you halfway through a crane.
I guess hobbies need patience, especially now.
Wasn’t much of a crowd tonight, surprisingly calm for the blackout.
I always bring some paper for origami—practice helps me focus.
Been folding more since everything shut down. Less distraction, but more tension.
It’s odd doing it by candlelight when the power’s out.
I taught a neighbor how to make a three-piece flower yesterday.
Felt good, even if the folds were crooked.
The downtime makes it easier to share things, for once.
No trouble tonight. Bar’s practically my refuge these days, especially after Council flagged me.
Origami’s my escape. Complex tessellations—sometimes I fold to keep from unraveling myself.
That first night of the blackout, I messed up a whole stack—couldn’t find the rhythm.
I used scrap BCI notices as folding paper. Irony, right?
Before, I hid the hobby. Now, people ask me to show them cranes.
Last week, someone brought an old map—wanted to see if it folded better.
Honestly, it feels like I belong here when I’m teaching it.
Never thought a blackout could bring people closer over something so small.
hobby_answer: Yeah. A few. Nothing fancy recently.
Been harder to find decent paper.
Blackout made it… impractical.
People keep knocking for supplies instead.
I did. Managed a crane after the blackout started.
Paper's all old transit schedules now.
Hard to fold with everyone restless in the building.
Hobby's quieter but also… not private anymore.
I miss the routine.
Couple cranes, actually. Made them when BCI crashed.
Used scrap flyers—no deliveries, no new stock since blackout.
People notice you folding now, ask for pieces.
Less digital distraction, more interruptions.
Blocks are louder, everyone's on edge.
I keep folding, but it's different.
Miss when it was just background habit.
Yeah, I've been folding. Keeps my mind straight, honestly.
After the BCI shutdown, the whole block's restless.
No screens, so I folded by candlelight with neighbors.
Paper's turned precious—old protocols and rosters work best now.
Had to improvise a lot, can't get my usual paper.
Folding calms the hands, even if the shapes look rough now.
Feels strange to share the process, it used to be private.
Something about uncertainty makes the patterns meaningful.
Definitely. Folding's the one habit I never dropped, even during the blackout.
I started in school—liked the control, the repeatable symmetry.
When BCI died, everything snapped to analog: candles, borrowed scissors, whispered stories.
My origami stash turned communal—rosters, protocols, blank forms became cranes.
It was awkward—everyone watching, waiting on my hands to work.
Miss the hum of the system for the focus it gave.
Funny, sharing paper brought neighbors together more than the Council ever did.
Crane wings got crooked, but no one cared much. Feels like folding against the current.
I keep thinking if the city rebuilds, this piece of quiet might not come back.
